articles.headline: The number of U.S. workers quitting their jobs in September was the highest on record.
articles.snippet: Nearly a million workers quit in the leisure and hospitality industry alone, reflecting the competition for workers after pandemic-induced shutdowns.
articles.abstract: Nearly a million workers quit in the leisure and hospitality industry alone, reflecting the competition for workers after pandemic-induced shutdowns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employers are still struggling to fill millions of open jobs — and to hold on to the workers they already have.

articles.headline: Menace Enters the Republican Mainstream
articles.snippet: Threats of violence have become commonplace among a significant part of the party, as historians and those who study democracy warn of a dark shift in American politics.
articles.abstract: Threats of violence have become commonplace among a significant part of the party, as historians and those who study democracy warn of a dark shift in American politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: On Podcasts and Radio, Misleading Covid-19 Talk Goes Unchecked
articles.snippet: False statements about vaccines have spread on the “Wild West” of media, even as some hosts die of virus complications.
articles.abstract: False statements about vaccines have spread on the “Wild West” of media, even as some hosts die of virus complications.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent episode of his podcast, Rick Wiles, a pastor and self-described “citizen reporter,” endorsed a conspiracy theory: that Covid-19 vaccines were the product of a “global coup d’état by the most evil cabal of people in the history of mankind.”
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Marc Tracy

articles.headline: Democrats’ Bill Would Deny For-Profit College Students Extra Aid
articles.snippet: Critics say a little-noticed provision would hurt the very constituencies — people of color, the working class, low-income Americans — that the party typically champions.
articles.abstract: Critics say a little-noticed provision would hurt the very constituencies — people of color, the working class, low-income Americans — that the party typically champions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Megan Kern decided she wanted to enroll in Pima Medical Institute, in Phoenix last year, its tax status was the furthest thing from her mind.

articles.headline: Bannon Indicted on Contempt Charges Over House’s Capitol Riot Inquiry
articles.snippet: Stephen K. Bannon, a former top aide to Donald Trump, had refused to comply with subpoenas from the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on Congress.
articles.abstract: Stephen K. Bannon, a former top aide to Donald Trump, had refused to comply with subpoenas from the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen K. Bannon, a onetime senior aide to former President Donald J. Trump, was indicted by a federal grand jury on Friday on two counts of contempt of Congress, after his refusal to provide information to the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: Johnson & Johnson, Iconic Company Under Pressure, Plans to Split in Two
articles.snippet: The 135-year-old company announced plans to divide itself into a consumer products business and a medical company.
articles.abstract: The 135-year-old company announced plans to divide itself into a consumer products business and a medical company.
articles.lead_paragraph: For generations, Johnson & Johnson has been synonymous with American health care — and, at times, with American health care scandals.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Robbins and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Peace Corps Volunteers Fall Through the Cracks of a Student Loan Fix
articles.snippet: A deserving group of dedicated people has been left out of the government’s latest patch for the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program.
articles.abstract: A deserving group of dedicated people has been left out of the government’s latest patch for the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Education Department announced fixes for its deeply dysfunctional Public Service Loan Forgiveness program last month, hundreds of thousands of long-suffering borrowers were suddenly given a chance at the kind of relief that the federal government had long promised them.

articles.headline: Migrants Say Belarusians Took Them to E.U. Border and Supplied Wire Cutters
articles.snippet: Iraqi Kurds and other migrants said they were fleeing despair at home, but Belarus encouraged them, offering visas and helping them get to the border.
articles.abstract: Iraqi Kurds and other migrants said they were fleeing despair at home, but Belarus encouraged them, offering visas and helping them get to the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the migrant crisis at the Belarus-Poland border.
articles.byline: By Jane Arraf and Elian Peltier

articles.headline: How the U.S. Hid an Airstrike That Killed Dozens of Civilians in Syria
articles.snippet: The military never conducted an independent investigation into a 2019 bombing on the last bastion of the Islamic State, despite concerns about a secretive commando force.
articles.abstract: The military never conducted an independent investigation into a 2019 bombing on the last bastion of the Islamic State, despite concerns about a secretive commando force.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last days of the battle against the Islamic State in Syria, when members of the once-fierce caliphate were cornered in a dirt field next to a town called Baghuz, a U.S. military drone circled high overhead, hunting for military targets. But it saw only a large crowd of women and children huddled against a river bank.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Can Self-Defense Laws Stand Up to a Country Awash in Guns?
articles.snippet: The Kyle Rittenhouse and Ahmaud Arbery cases raise intriguing legal questions about people who take the law into their own hands and then claim self-defense when someone dies.
articles.abstract: The Kyle Rittenhouse and Ahmaud Arbery cases raise intriguing legal questions about people who take the law into their own hands and then claim self-defense when someone dies.
articles.lead_paragraph: As two closely watched murder trials played out in two different states this past week, juries heard strikingly similar stories: men took up guns in the name of protecting the public, and when they wound up killing unarmed people, they claimed self-defense.

articles.headline: The Crypto Capital of the World
articles.snippet: It has to be somewhere. Why not Ukraine?
articles.abstract: It has to be somewhere. Why not Ukraine?
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A buccaneering 37-year-old educated in a British private school, Michael Chobanian is fluent both in English and the folkways of Ukraine, which he regards as a largely lawless frontier and which he likes to traverse in his black Ferrari 612. He is the founder of Kuna, one of Eastern Europe’s first cryptocurrency exchanges. To him,  his native country is a terrific place to run a business, as long as you have the nerve to navigate a system rife with corruption.
articles.byline: By David Segal and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: How a School District Got Caught in Virginia’s Political Maelstrom
articles.snippet: Loudoun County tried to address racism and promote diversity within its schools. Then it found itself on Fox News.
articles.abstract: Loudoun County tried to address racism and promote diversity within its schools. Then it found itself on Fox News.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEESBURG, Va. — Long before the father was tackled by sheriff’s deputies at the school board meeting, before there was shouting to reopen classrooms and before “parents matter” became the central slogan of the most closely watched campaign in the post-Trump era, Loudoun County was just another American suburbia taking a hard look at its schools.

articles.headline: Crunch at Ports May Mean Crisis for American Farms
articles.snippet: Backlogs and cancellations are hitting growers as costs rise, profits slump and overseas customers shop elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Backlogs and cancellations are hitting growers as costs rise, profits slump and overseas customers shop elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s just 60 miles from El Dorado Dairy in Ontario, Calif., to the nation’s largest container port in Los Angeles. But the farm is having little luck getting its products onto a ship headed for the foreign markets that are crucial to its business.

articles.headline: They Warned Their Names Were on a Hit List. They Were Killed.
articles.snippet: In less than a month, assassins have killed at least eight people in the Rohingya refugee camps of Bangladesh, silencing those who have dared to speak out against the violent gangs.
articles.abstract: In less than a month, assassins have killed at least eight people in the Rohingya refugee camps of Bangladesh, silencing those who have dared to speak out against the violent gangs.
articles.lead_paragraph: At night in the refugee camps, with only a thin tarpaulin wall as protection, Mohammed waits for the men to come and kill him.

articles.headline: ‘Ghost Guns’: Firearm Kits Bought Online Fuel Epidemic of Violence
articles.snippet: They are untraceable, assembled from parts and can be ordered by gang members, felons and even children. They are increasingly the lethal weapon of easy access around the U.S., but especially California.
articles.abstract: They are untraceable, assembled from parts and can be ordered by gang members, felons and even children. They are increasingly the lethal weapon of easy access around the U.S., but especially California.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Biden’s Child Care Plan Faces Resistance From Religious Groups
articles.snippet: A nondiscrimination provision in the $1.85 trillion social policy bill could disqualify some religious organizations, spurring a fight over who can benefit from President Biden’s landmark bill.
articles.abstract: A nondiscrimination provision in the $1.85 trillion social policy bill could disqualify some religious organizations, spurring a fight over who can benefit from President Biden’s landmark bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A coalition of conservative religious groups is waging an intensive lobbying effort to remove a nondiscrimination provision from President Biden’s ambitious prekindergarten and child care plans, fearing it would disqualify their programs from receiving a huge new infusion of federal money.

articles.headline: His Reasons for Opposing Trump Were Biblical. Now a Top Christian Editor Is Out.
articles.snippet: A clash over culture and politics comes to World, a groundbreaking journalistic institution that covers evangelical Christians.
articles.abstract: A clash over culture and politics comes to World, a groundbreaking journalistic institution that covers evangelical Christians.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Marvin Olasky gets angry emails from readers — more often than not about an exposé of wrongdoing at an evangelical church, or about a story that reflects poorly on Donald Trump — he has a stock reply.

articles.headline: The Consulting Firm Billionaires Turn to When They Give Away Money
articles.snippet: A little-known organization called the Bridgespan Group is guiding the philanthropic choices of many leading donors, including MacKenzie Scott.
articles.abstract: A little-known organization called the Bridgespan Group is guiding the philanthropic choices of many leading donors, including MacKenzie Scott.
articles.lead_paragraph: MacKenzie Scott stepped out of the long shadow of her former husband, the Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, by handing out billions of dollars in grants over the past two years to charities, community colleges, food banks and progressive nonprofits led by people of color.

articles.headline: Republicans Gain Heavy House Edge in 2022 as Gerrymandered Maps Emerge
articles.snippet: On a highly distorted congressional map that is still taking shape, the party has added enough safe House districts to capture control of the chamber based on its redistricting edge alone.
articles.abstract: On a highly distorted congressional map that is still taking shape, the party has added enough safe House districts to capture control of the chamber based on its redistricting edge alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A year before the polls open in the 2022 midterm elections, Republicans are already poised to flip at least five seats in the closely divided House thanks to redrawn district maps that are more distorted, more disjointed and more gerrymandered than any since the Voting Rights Act was passed in 1965.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Four Lives Lost: Inside America’s Homicide Surge
articles.snippet: In many cities, towns and rural areas, homicides are up in 2021, even after a sharp rise last year. The reasons are elusive. The impact is immeasurable. Here are four stories from one month that offer a glimpse of the toll.
articles.abstract: In many cities, towns and rural areas, homicides are up in 2021, even after a sharp rise last year. The reasons are elusive. The impact is immeasurable. Here are four stories from one month that offer a glimpse of the toll.
articles.lead_paragraph: A hot dog vendor walking out of a downtown ballpark, where gunfire pierced the night after the home team won a game. A woman whose quarrel with a trusted friend took a heartbreaking turn. A young man caught up in drugs passing through a shabby motel. A new mother shot by a stranger in a random act of extreme violence.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Mitch Smith, Neil MacFarquhar, Tim Arango, Chloe Reynolds, Adria Malcolm, Mason Trinca, Cydni Elledge and Stephen Speranza

articles.headline: Wall St. Is Finally Getting Access to China. But for How Long?
articles.snippet: Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs are among those eyeing huge potential profits, undeterred by Beijing’s sudden policy changes and friction with the United States.
articles.abstract: Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs are among those eyeing huge potential profits, undeterred by Beijing’s sudden policy changes and friction with the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow live updates on the upcoming meeting between President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping.]
